Getting Orca-2

Overview of dependencies

The diagram below shows an overview of dependencies between Orca-2 and external libraries. Orca-2 distribution is shown in yellow. Source code modules distributed with Orca are highlighted. External libraries are shown in white. Dependencies are indicated by dashed arrows.

orca2 contains objects and interface definitions. The distribution also contains a repository of working, documented components contributed by the developer community. It also contains some examples. The utilities contained in the distribution are strictly optional. Practically, this means that you can download build your own components from scratch and communicate with the existing components. Individual components may have their own dependencies as illustrated in the diagram but they never depend on each other.

Download and install instructions

Follow these instructions to download and install orca2. For concreteness, commands for installing dependencies under Debian Linux are provided. Send feedback on building under other distributions.

  1. CMake: Cross-Platform Make. 
    # apt-get install cmake
  2. Download and install Ice libraries. Orca-2 has been tested with versions up to 2.1.2. Full instructions are available from the download page.
    • First, install Ice dependencies. In debian packages for all required libraries exist.
      • # apt-get install libdb4.2++-dev libbz2-dev bzip2 libssl-dev libreadline5-dev libexpat1-dev
    • Get Ice distribution from ZerocC
    • Unpack the distribution
      • $ tar -xzf Ice-[VERSION].tar.gz
$ cd Ice-[VERSION]
    • Suggestion: change the installation directory to something more standard. This is done by editing the 'config/Make.rules' file. This will install all Ice stuff into /usr/local.
      • ...
prefix                  = /usr/local
...
    • Ice is particular about the name of the compiler. Make sure the names are standard: gcc/g++! If you skip this step you'll see a cryptic message about 'mkshlib' not defined.
      • $ export CC=gcc
$ export CXX=g++
    • Make
      • $ make
$ make test (optional, requires python)
# make install
# ldconfig
  3. Download and install any optional dependencies you'd like:
    • Player/Stage, is required for some hardware support and for use of the Stage simulator (you probably want this).
      • IMPORTANT: Player version 1.6 or later is required!
    • Doxygen for generating local doxygen documentation
      • # apt-get install doxygen
    • Qt, is required for a Graphical User Interface.
      • Qt v.3.0 or later is required. Tested with versions up to 3.3.3
      # apt-get install libqt3-mt-dev
  4. Build and install Orca-2 distribution:
    • Download the latest release of orca-components.
    • Un-tar the release.
    • configure using cmake (note the dot after cmake)
    • compile, and install.
    $ tar -zxvf orca2-x.x.x.tar.gz
$ cd orca-components
$ cmake .
$ make
# make install
# ldconfig

Getting Orca from CVS

(Not yet converted to Orca-2)

You can get detailed instructions of how to get Orca from CVS here.
Short instructions:

  • Registered developers should use ssh-based login, others should use anonymous login.
  • Anonymous Login: cvs -d:pserver:anonymous@cvs.sourceforge.net:/cvsroot/orca-robotics login
  • Anonymous Checkout:
    • cvs -z3 -d:pserver:anonymous@cvs.sourceforge.net:/cvsroot/orca-robotics co orca-base
    • cvs -z3 -d:pserver:anonymous@cvs.sourceforge.net:/cvsroot/orca-robotics co orca-components
